qas.question: What were the majority of the differences in the revised budget due to the temporary changing of?
When were expenses recorded by the new government?

answers.text: when military material was ordered rather than received

qas.question: What did retroactively applying the ESA95 methodology result in raising the budget deficit to?
By how much did the budget deficit of Greece exceed the 3% limit in the reference year of 1999?
What other European country were claims similar to those levied against Greece made?
What had no differences in the revised budget?

plausible_answers.text: when military material was ordered rather than received

qas.question: When were expenses classified by the new government?
What did retroactively applying the ESA95 methodology result in lowering the budget deficit to?
How much did the budget deficit of Greece decrease the 3% limit in the reference year of 1994?
What other European country were claims similar to those levied against Greece restricted?

context: Most of the differences in the revised budget deficit numbers were due to a temporary change of <a0_0><b5_0>accounting practices<b5_0/><a0_0/> by the new government, i.e., recording expenses <a1_0><b6_0>when military material was ordered rather than received<b6_0/><a1_0/>. However, it was the retroactive application of ESA95 methodology (applied since 2000) by Eurostat, that finally raised the reference year (1999) budget deficit to <a2_0><b7_0><b8_0>3<a3_0>.38%<b8_0/><a3_0/> of GDP<b7_0/><a2_0/>, thus exceeding the 3% limit. This led to claims that Greece (similar claims have been made about other European countries like <a4_0><b9_0>Italy<b9_0/><a4_0/>) had not actually met all five accession criteria, and the common perception that Greece entered the Eurozone through "falsified" deficit numbers.
